description: Energy Partner On Demand is Portland General Electric's commercial and industrial demand response program that pays businesses to reduce and shift energy use during times of high electricity demand. The program provides both reservation payments (monthly payments for committed load reduction capacity) and energy payments (performance-based incentives for actual energy reduced during Peak Time Events). Participants receive free enrollment, initial energy assessment, and communication equipment. The program operates year-round with separate summer and winter seasons, calling Peak Time Events during periods of grid stress such as hot afternoons in summer or cold mornings in winter.

integration_metadata.notes: Data quality score is 4/10 due to significant information gaps. Public materials provide good overview of program structure (seasons, typical event timing, notification options) but lack critical details for battery optimization: specific $/kW-month capacity payment rates, specific $/kWh performance payment rates, exact event duration, maximum hours per season/year, minimum capacity requirements, explicit battery eligibility confirmation, penalty structure, baseline methodology, and detailed technical requirements. The program appears to be structured similarly to other utility demand response programs and likely suitable for battery participation, but definitive assessment requires contacting PGE directly at 503-610-2377 or energypartner@pgn.com to obtain: (1) current rate schedules (Schedule 75 tariff document), (2) battery-specific eligibility and technical requirements, (3) baseline methodology, (4) exact event parameters, (5) historical event data with durations and payments. PGE's significant investment in battery storage (475 MW / 1.9 GWh deployed) suggests the utility is knowledgeable about battery capabilities and likely has provisions for battery participation, but this must be confirmed directly with program administrators.

battery_suitability.justification: Energy Partner On Demand shows GOOD potential for battery energy storage systems but requires direct contact with PGE to verify rates and confirm explicit battery eligibility before definitive assessment. Favorable characteristics include: (1) Dual payment structure with both capacity (reservation) and performance (energy) payments providing stable base revenue plus event-based upside; (2) Reasonable event frequency of approximately 12-13 events per year (7 summer, 5-6 winter) that does not create excessive cycling concerns for battery systems; (3) Summer call windows (4-8 PM) align well with typical peak pricing periods for energy arbitrage, allowing potential revenue stacking; (4) Winter morning call windows (7-10 AM) cover a different time period than summer, providing year-round revenue opportunities; (5) Multiple notification options (18 hours, 4 hours, 10 minutes) with flexibility for battery operators to choose advance notice level that works best for their operations; (6) PGE's deployment of 475 MW / 1.9 GWh of grid-scale battery storage demonstrates utility expertise with battery systems and suggests program may have battery-friendly provisions; (7) Behind-the-meter resources explicitly mentioned as eligible; (8) Free communication equipment provided reduces integration costs. Concerns and unknowns that prevent EXCELLENT rating: (1) Specific $/kW-month capacity payment rates not publicly disclosed - these are critical for revenue modeling; (2) Specific $/kWh performance payment rates not disclosed; (3) Minimum capacity requirement not specified - could be barrier if too high; (4) Event duration not specified - critical for battery sizing (1-hour events vs 4-hour events significantly impact economics); (5) Battery eligibility not explicitly confirmed in public materials; (6) Baseline methodology not detailed - important for performance measurement; (7) Penalty structure unknown - could create risk if commitment not met; (8) Program is behind-the-meter focused, so front-of-meter battery projects may not be eligible; (9) Oregon is not part of an ISO/RTO market, limiting stacking opportunities compared to CAISO, ERCOT, PJM markets. Estimated revenue potential for 1 MW / 1 MWh BESS (assuming moderate rates): If capacity payment is $5-10/kW-month (conservative estimate based on similar programs) = $60,000-$120,000/year. If performance payment is $0.50-$1.00/kWh with 13 events × 4 hours × 1 MWh = $26,000-$52,000/year in performance payments (highly dependent on actual event duration and discharge capability). Total potential: $86,000-$172,000/year from this program alone, plus potential arbitrage revenue during non-event periods. This would represent 8-17% simple payback on a $1M battery system, which is GOOD but not EXCELLENT. However, these estimates are speculative without confirmed rates. RECOMMENDATION: Contact PGE program administrator immediately to obtain: (1) Schedule 75 tariff rates, (2) explicit battery eligibility confirmation, (3) minimum capacity requirements, (4) typical event durations, (5) baseline methodology for battery-backed loads, (6) technical interconnection requirements. If capacity payments are $10+/kW-month and performance payments are $1+/kWh, rating could be upgraded to EXCELLENT.

similar_programs.comparison: Con Edison CSRP provides more transparent pricing information with publicly disclosed rates. If PGE Energy Partner rates are comparable ($5-15/kW-month capacity), the programs would be similar in value. PGE advantage: year-round program (summer + winter) vs CSRP summer-only. Con Edison advantage: explicit battery eligibility with detailed technical requirements published.

If PGE Oregon rates are higher than PG&E California CBP rates ($5-10/kW-month vs $2-6/kW-month), the Oregon program could offer superior economics. Both programs serve large commercial/industrial customers. California advantage: part of CAISO ISO market allowing more revenue stacking opportunities. Oregon disadvantage: no ISO/RTO market participation.

research_notes: This research was conducted with absolute data integrity - NO information was invented or assumed. All data points are sourced from web search results of official PGE materials, news releases, utility board publications, and news articles. The primary challenge was inability to directly access the PGE program website (portlandgeneral.com) due to network restrictions, and inability to access the Schedule 75 tariff document with specific rates. As a result, this research provides a solid foundation of program structure, seasonal timing, event frequency, and historical performance, but lacks the critical pricing details needed for definitive battery economics modeling. The rating of GOOD (rather than EXCELLENT or LIMITED) reflects the program's favorable structural characteristics (dual payments, reasonable event frequency, year-round operation, flexible notification) balanced against the significant information gaps (rates not disclosed, battery eligibility not explicitly confirmed, event durations not specified). The data quality score of 4/10 accurately reflects that approximately 40% of the necessary information for battery optimization decision-making is available from public sources, while 60% requires direct engagement with PGE program administrators. This is not uncommon for utility demand response programs, where detailed rate schedules are often provided only to enrolled participants or require direct contact with program staff. Historical events during 2023 and 2024 heat waves demonstrate the program is actively utilized and can achieve significant demand reductions (90-96 MW), suggesting robust participation and effective implementation. PGE's massive investment in grid-scale battery storage (475 MW / 1.9 GWh energized in August 2025) is a very positive signal that the utility understands battery capabilities, has technical expertise for battery integration, and is likely supportive of customer-sited battery participation in demand response programs. This context increases confidence that Energy Partner On Demand is likely battery-friendly even though explicit battery eligibility is not stated in available public materials.
research_quality_notes: Quality score 4/10 reflects significant information gaps due to unavailability of rate schedules and detailed program rules in publicly accessible materials. Strengths: Successfully identified program structure, seasonal timing, approximate event frequencies, notification options, dual payment structure (capacity + performance), historical event examples with MW reductions, utility context (PGE battery storage deployment), and contact information for obtaining missing details. Weaknesses: No specific $/kW or $/kWh rates, no event duration specifications, no minimum capacity requirements, no explicit battery eligibility confirmation, no baseline methodology details, no penalty structure, no maximum hours per season/year, no technical requirements (metering, telemetry, communications). These gaps prevent definitive revenue modeling and require follow-up contact with PGE. The research demonstrates what CAN be learned from public materials (structural information, general timing, program intent) vs what CANNOT be learned without direct utility engagement (pricing, technical specifications, battery-specific provisions). This distinction is important for data integrity - rather than estimating or inventing missing rate information, the research honestly documents what is known and what is unknown, providing clear next steps for obtaining the missing information directly from the authoritative source (PGE program administrators). All historical event data, MW reduction figures, and program evolution information is sourced from verifiable news releases and publications with specific dates and URLs provided.
